content.prompt:
Why Study Newton Scooters?


, in this unit, you will build a cart and try to get it to go as far as possible. We will show you how to make a better car by thinking about energy, where it comes from and where it goes.

components.prompt: Before we get started, describe in detail how you think a self-propelled vehicle, or Newton Scooter, works!

content.prompt:
Your Ideas About How Newton Scooters Work

 

A rubber band car is a type of Newton Scooter!

With materials right in your own home, you can build a Newton Scooter!  For each of the following write down your best ideas about what might affect how far a Newton Scooter might travel.

components.prompt: Where does the energy needed to move the rubber band car come from?
How do the materials you use affect how far your car travels?

components.html:
How Do Newton Scooters Work?

To help you make good design choices, lets explore some important science concepts for Newton Scooters:

  • Potential Energy
  • Kinetic Energy
  • Thermal Energy

content.prompt:
Potential Energy: Rubber Band Cars

 

Potential energy is STORED energy. It is energy that is available to do a task.

One type of Newton Scooter, a rubber band car, can explain the concepts. To give a rubber band car potential energy, we pull (or wind) a rubber band. The rubber band stores energy so that the car will be able to move.

Think about a bow and arrow. How is the bow like a rubber band in the car?

components.prompt: When does the bow have elastic potential energy?

choices.text: When it is lying on the ground
When it is pulled back
When it is released and has stopped moving

content.prompt:
Kinetic Energy: Rubber Band Cars

Kinetic energy is MOVEMENT energy.

When we let go of the rubber band, the potential energy gets transformed into kinetic energy and the car moves.

The more potential energy the rubber band stores, the more energy there is to transform into kinetic energy, the farther the car can go!

components.prompt: Now think about a bow and arrow. When is the potential energy transformed into kinetic energy?

choices.text: When the arrow is attached to the bow
When the arrow hits the target
When the arrow is released

content.prompt:
The skateboarder starts at the top right and contines down the ramp.

A B C

components.prompt: Which skateboarder has the most kinetic energy?

choices.text: A
B
C

components.prompt: Explain why she has the most kinetic energy.

components.html:
On the next page you will be experimenting with a skateboarder on a ramp.

  1. Click on the "Bar Graph" box on the right-hand side of the screen.
  2. Place the skateboarder at different heights on the ramp and see how potential and kinetic energy change.
  3. Press the pause button 3 times at different locations on the ramp. What do you notice about how potential and kinetic energy change?

nodes.title: How Are Potential and Kinetic Energy Related?

components.prompt: How is the air leaving a blown up balloon like the skateboarder leaving the top of the ramp? Talk about how potential and kinetic energy change in your response.
How does the potential and kinetic energy change when the air leaves a blown up balloon?
How does potential and kinetic energy change when the skateboarder leaves the top of the ramp?

components.html: Click the green arrow to go on to the next step!

Guidelines for Your Newton Scooter


Rules: Your Newton Scooter Must:

  • Use elastic potential energy. BE CREATIVE! There are many types of elastic that can provide potential energy for your scooter!
  • NOT use gravitational potential energy or electricity.
  • Be self-propelled (you can't give it a push to start)
  • Have all pieces traveling together (no slingshotting)

Goals: A successful Newton Scotter will:

  • Travel 2 meters.
  • Travel within a 1 meter wide track (your scooter can't fly around everywhere).

content.prompt:
Newton Scooters

Car 1


rubber band car

Car 2


water bottle
rubber band cars

Car 3


balloon car

components.prompt: Choose TWO cars. Describe how the features of one car could help it move farther than the other.

content.prompt:
Elastic Potential Energy

 

There are many types of elastic potential energy. In all cases of elastic potential energy, elastic or a spring is stretched (deformed). The stretched elastic or spring stores the potential energy. The more it is stretched, the more potential energy it has.

Below are some examples of Newton Scooters using elastic potential energy.

Car 1

Car 2

Car 3

The mousetrap car stores elastic potential energy in the spring of the mousetrap.

The balloon car stores elastic potential energy in the inflated balloon.

Where does the above scooter store elastic potential energy?

components.prompt: How can you increase the elastic potential energy of Car 3?

content.prompt:
Elastic Potential Energy

 

There are many types of elastic potential energy. In all cases of elastic potential energy, elastic or a spring is stretched (deformed). The stretched elastic or spring stores the potential energy. The more it is stretched, the more potential energy it has.

The following pages present examples of Newton Scooters using elastic potential energy.

Evaluate Potential Energy

The mousetrap car stores elastic potential energy in the spring of the mousetrap.

Evaluate Potential Energy

The balloon car stores elastic potential energy in the inflated balloon.

Evaluate Potential Energy

Where does the above scooter store elastic potential energy?

components.prompt: How can you increase the elastic potential energy of the car above?

components.html: Click the green arrow to go on to the next step!

content.prompt:
Design Your Own Newton Scooter!

Plan the design for your Newton Scooter! Consider all the possible design choices such as:

  • The size of the wheels
  • The thickness of the rubber band
  • The size of the balloon
  • The material of the body
  • The nature of the axel

In this activity you will investigate the feature you think is most important.

components.prompt: Identify a feature you want to investigate (wheel size, balloon shape, body material, rubber band thickness, ).
Predict which design of your feature (bigger wheels, thicker rubber band) will make the Newton Scooter go farther.
Explain why changing your feature impacts the distance your Newton Scooter travels.

content.prompt:
Friction

Where else does potential energy go? Some potential energy becomes thermal energy, which is caused by friction. Friction is the resistance between one surface when it is in contact with another surface.


POTENTIAL ENERGY -> KINETIC ENERGY + THERMAL ENERGY (from friction)

components.prompt: Where is there friction on your Newton Scooter?
What do you think would happen if there were NO friction?

components.html:
On the next page you will be experimenting with a skateboarder on a ramp again.

Be sure to change the FRICTION slider to see how it affects potential and kinetic energy.

nodes.title: Potential Energy, Kinetic Energy, and Friction

content.prompt:
Potentional energy, kinetic energy, and thermal energy are all related.
Potential energy can transform into kinetic energy, but it can also be lost to thermal energy.

More Friction

When the skateboarder is at the top of the ramp, she has her maximum potential energy.This ramp has a rougher surface, so there is a lot of friction.

As the skateboarder goes down the ramp, friction creates thermal energy. With a lot of friction, the skateboarder did not have very much kinetic energy (movement energy). She will not travel very far.

Less Friction

When the skateboarder is at the top of the ramp, she has her maximum potential energy.This ramp has a smoother surface, so there is not a lot of friction.

With only a little bit of friction, the skateboarder has more energy transformed into kinetic energy (movement energy). She will travel far.

Car 1

Car 2
The above cars are exactly the same. Car 1 travelled 2 meters down a smooth track. Car 2 only travelled 1 meter down a rough track.

components.prompt: Both cars had their balloons blown up with the same amount of air to start the race. Why did Car 1 travel farther than Car 2?

choices.text: It had more potential energy and less kinetic energy.
It had less potential energy and more kinetic energy.
It had less kinetic energy because more potential energy was transformed into thermal energy.
It had more kinetic energy because less potential energy  was transformed into thermal energy.

components.html:
Designing Your Newton Scooter


With your partner sketch (on paper) a design of your Newton Scooter. 

When you are designing your scooter, keep in mind you will be testing how far your scooter goes and how long it moves.

components.prompt:
Take a picture of your drawing and upload your design!

Using the draw tools, indicate where your scooter will store POTENTIAL ENERGY and where there will be FRICTION.

content.prompt: Materials List

components.prompt: In the space below, list what materials you will need to construct your Newton Scooter.

components.html:
Time to Build Your Newton Scooter


It's time to build your Newton Scooter!

Gather all of your materials and start building!

content.prompt:
Building Log: Day 2

Potential Energy = Kinetic Energy + Thermal Energy (heat caused by friction)

components.prompt: What issues did you have during building yesterday? Be sure to discuss potential energy, kinetic energy, and/or thermal energy in your response.
How do you plan to improve your vehicle today?

components.prompt: What issues did you have during building yesterday? Be sure to discuss potential energy, kinetic energy, and/or thermal energy in your response.

components.html:
Test Your Newton Scooter!


  1. Take a timer and one computer to the testing station.
  2. Test your Newton Scooter!
  3. Record the time and distance your scooter travels.

components.prompt:
RECORD YOUR DATA

Below is a table for you to record data from testing your Newton Scooter.

Test your scooter 3 times. Record how long your scooter traveled (in seconds) and how far your scooter traveled (in cm). After you input your data, respond to the question below.
In the space below describe your table. What does it tell us about your scooter?

nodes.title: Take a picture and critique a Newton Scooter

components.prompt:
1. Take a picture of your Newton Scooter and upload it here. Press SAVE!

2. Have TWO other classmates answer these questions. They should write their responses as a comment to your picture. Press SAVE after each classmate responds.

  • How does this scooter store potential energy well or how could it be improved?
  • How does this scooter use kinetic energy well or how could it be improved?

content.prompt: Improvements

components.prompt: How could your scooter store more potential energy? Why?
How could your scooter have more kinetic energy? Why?
Which balloon car and which skateboarder have only potential energy (A, B, or C)?
Why does that balloon car and that skateboarder only have potential energy?
Which balloon car has only potential energy (A, B, or C)?
Why does that balloon car only have potential energy?
Which skateboarder has only potential energy (A, B, or C)?
Why does that skateboarder only have potential energy?

components.html: Click the green arrow to go on to the next step!

Design Build Test!

 

Now that you designed, built, and tested your Newton Scooter, it's time to give it another try!
Using feedback and your own experiences, think about how you can make better design choices. Redesign, rebuild, and retest your new and improved Newton Scooter!

Designing Your Newton Scooter

Update the design sketche you made for your first scooter. You can add to your original design or you can begin on a new piece of paper.

components.prompt:
Take a picture of your drawing and upload your design!

Using the draw tools, indicate where your scooter will store POTENTIAL ENERGY and where there will be FRICTION.

Was your second scooter more successful than your first scooter? How are you measuring success?

No
